title: Hundreds more China ship dead found
desc: A total of 331 people have been confirmed dead following the righting of the Eastern Star cruise ship which capsized on Monday in the Yangtze River.

title: India Bangladesh to seal land pact
desc: Bangladesh and India are to sign a historic agreement to simplify their common border by exchanging more than 150 enclaves of land.

title: Cameron wants world corruption purge
desc: UK Prime Minister David Cameron will urge world leaders at the G7 summit to take corruption more seriously in the wake of the Fifa scandal.

title: Dozens die in Yemen border fighting
desc: Four Saudi soldiers and dozens of Yemeni rebels are killed in intense fighting along the two countries' border the Saudi-led coalition says.

title: Don't humiliate Greece - PM Tsipras
desc: Alexis Tsipras warns Greece's international creditors not to impose humiliating terms as the country seeks urgently needed bailout funds.

title: US facing 'dedicated' hacking enemy
desc: The US says it faces a dedicated adversary and an ever evolving threat to the nation's cyber security after a major data breach.

title: Tariq Aziz ex-Saddam aide dies
desc: Tariq Aziz known as the face of Saddam Hussein's regime on the world stage for many years has died in an Iraqi hospital officials say.

title: Malaysia mountain quake kills 11
desc: Eleven people die and eight are missing after an earthquake near Malaysia's highest peak but 137 climbers trapped there are now safe officials say.

title: Violence ahead of Mexico elections
desc: There have been several incidences of violence around Mexico as the country prepares for Sunday's mid-term elections.

title: Billion could see Women's World Cup
desc: The World Cup could reach up to a billion TV viewers as hosts Canada kick off the biggest staging of the tournament on Saturday.

title: Mugabe stepson fined for manslaughter
desc: The eldest son of Zimbabwe's first lady Grace Mugabe is convicted of manslaughter and fined $800 (£520) for knocking down a man in his car.

title: Third Mexico mountain mummy found
desc: Mountaineers on Mexico's Pico de Orizaba discover the mummified remains of a young man the third body to be found there in recent months.

title: VIDEO: US warns of growing hacking threat
desc: The US says it faces a dedicated adversary and an ever evolving threat to the nation's cyber security after a major data breach.

title: VIDEO: China police block BBC filming at protest
desc: Relatives of missing passengers who were on board the Chinese cruise ship that sank on Monday stage a protest.

title: VIDEO: Replica French warship arrives in US
desc: A replica of the Hermione the ship that transported a French general to America in 1780 to support the US in its fight for independence has arrived in Yorktown America.

title: VIDEO: Mexico protesters look to disrupt vote
desc: Protesters and police have clashed in several states in Mexico ahead of the mid-term elections.

title: VIDEO: Sorokin: Russia 2018 bid was clean
desc: The head of the organising committee for the Russia 2018 World Cup has insisted that the bid was clean transparent and done in accordance with all the practices that are in place in Fifa.

title: VIDEO: Face-to-face with IS militants
desc: The BBC's Orla Guerin is given exclusive access to members of an alleged Islamic State militant cell.

title: VIDEO: Greek PM: Bailout plan 'unrealistic'
desc: Alexis Tsipras warns Greece's creditors not to impose humiliating terms on his country as it seeks bailout funds.

title: VIDEO: Anger over Maggi noodles withdrawal
desc: India's food safety regulator bans the production of Nestle's Maggi instant noodles over fears about their safety.

title: The real scars of Korean gaming
desc: In South Korea e-sports stars are adored celebrities. Dave Lee gets up close to learn about the real impact of pro-gaming.

title: Turkey's least predictable election for over a decade
desc: In this polarised country supporters and opponents of the government await the outcome of the general election says Selin Girit.

title: Nervous times awaiting Greece's next move
desc: The Greek prime minister remains an unknown quantity and that makes Europe's economists and politicians pretty nervous.

title: Is Ferguson unrest behind murder spike?
desc: Murder rates in US cities have spiked. Some say it's due to a chilling effect on police while others call it a statistical aberration.

title: Obituary: Australia's Alan Bond
desc: The BBC takes a look at the life of Alan Bond the controversial businessman who funded Australia's America's Cup win and has died aged 77.

title: The 'conquerable' Mount Kinabalu
desc: Tens of thousands climb Malaysia's Mount Kinabalu but the popularity of the 4095m peak masks a dangerous side.

title: Sculptor defends 'vagina' artwork
desc: The British sculptor Anish Kapoor comes under fire for artwork in the French palace of Versailles that has been called dirty and gross.

title: Princess's christening announced
desc: Princess Charlotte will be christened by the Archbishop of Canterbury at the Queen's Sandringham estate on 5 July Kensington Palace says.

title: US economy adds 280000 jobs in May
desc: The US economy adds 280000 jobs in May much better than analysts had expected and the biggest increase this year.

title: Opec oil output fix boosts prices
desc: Oil prices rise then fall then rise again after Opec oil ministers keep their current production levels unchanged.

title: Power beamed to camera via wi-fi
desc: Ambient wi-fi signals have been used by US researchers to power a small surveillance camera.

title: First Steam Machines up for sale
desc: The first Steam Machines - an attempt to bring PC gaming to a wider audience - are available to pre-order.

title: Performers take part in BBC Music Day
desc: Hundreds of musicians are taking part in BBC Music Day - a UK-wide celebration of sound - with events in Glasgow Cardiff and Belfast

title: Steve Martin receives AFI tribute
desc: A host of stars have paid tribute to Steve Martin as he received the American Film Institute's life achievement award.

title: Verges 'last refuge for wild flowers'
desc: More than 700 species of wild plants - almost half of the native flora of the British Isles - are found on road verges according to a study.

title: Airbus details re-usable rocket idea
desc: Airbus which leads the production of Europe's Ariane rocket has developed a concept that could make future vehicles partially re-usable.

title: Court backs France over right to die
desc: The European Court of Human Rights allows France to take a paralysed man off life support in a case which divides his family.

title: 'Female Viagra' nears US approval
desc: A US government panel recommends approval for a drug treating low female libido providing patients are warned of possible strong side effects.

title: Neymar hails Barca strikers' bond
desc: Juventus and Barcelona prepare to contest the Champions League final with Barca star Neymar calling it the biggest game of his career.

title: Hamilton crashes in Canada rain
desc: Lewis Hamilton sets the pace and then crashes in a rain-interrupted second practice session at the Canadian Grand Prix.

title: How 1970s deodorant is still doing harm
desc: Fluorine is an evil gas. It is also used to manufacture a string of artificial gases some of which are fuelling global warming decades after they were sprayed out of aerosol cans.

title: Have 1200 World Cup workers really died in Qatar?
desc: The scandal surrounding Fifa has focused attention on the workers who have died building stadiums in Qatar - how reliable is the much-cited figure of 1200 deaths?

title: Fake orca used to scare sea lions
desc: The Oregon port city of Astoria goes to great lengths to rid itself of hundreds of sea lions - by bringing in a fake orca whale.

title: Japan monument honours dead insects
desc: Anatomist hopes to highlight insects' importance.

title: Witnesses questioned over Ghana fire
desc: Ghanaians are being questioned about the cause of a fire in which some 150 people died as they sought shelter from rain in a petrol station.

title: India regulator bans Maggi noodles
desc: India's food safety regulator says tests have found that Nestle India's Maggi instant noodle products are unsafe and hazardous.

title: 'Two dead' in Turkey election blasts
desc: At least two people have died and 100 injured in two explosions at a Kurdish opposition rally two days before Turkey's general election officials say.

title: Colombia searches for kidnapped girl
desc: Colombian officials launch a widescale search for the 11-year-old daughter of a high-profile security official who was kidnapped outside her school.

title: British Museum 'guarding' Syria loot
desc: The British Museum is guarding a precious artefact that was looted from Syria in the hope of returning it when the country is stable.

title: Jail term over Boston bomb cover-up
desc: A friend of Boston bomber Dzhokhar Tsarnaev has been sentenced to three and a half years in prison for obstructing the police investigation.

title: Down's blood test 'would cut risk'
desc: A blood test for Down's syndrome can reduce the number of pregnant women needing risky tests say UK doctors.

title: End of the line for rail vouchers
desc: Millions of rail passengers who suffer travel delays will soon be able to claim refunds in cash after a major policy change the BBC learns.

desc: UKIP leader Nigel Farage will present the party as a key voice in the campaign against the UK's membership of the EU during its first post-election conference.

desc: Portraits of D-Day veterans commissioned by the Prince of Wales go on public display at Buckingham Palace.
